senses.de: The quality of being graceful and stylish
senses.ex: She carries herself with such elegance.

Tips.title: Social Context
Tips.description: Used to compliment someone's appearance or behavior in social events.
Tips.example: At the gala, his elegance was unmatched.

Tips.title: Classiness Implied
Tips.description: Suggests a refined, high-class manner or appearance without arrogance.
Tips.example: Her simple yet elegant dress made a statement.

Tips.title: Not Just Visual
Tips.description: Can refer to actions and behavior, not just physical appearance.
Tips.example: He handled the situation with remarkable elegance.

senses.de: The quality of being pleasingly ingenious and simple
senses.ex: This mathematical solution shows great elegance.

Tips.title: Intellectual Praise
Tips.description: Used to admire the intelligence behind something done simply yet effectively.
Tips.example: Her presentation was praised for its elegance.

Tips.title: Unexpected Solution
Tips.description: 'Elegance' can describe a surprisingly simple solution to a complex problem.
Tips.example: He found an elegant solution to the engineering challenge.

Tips.title: Academic Approval
Tips.description: Often used in academic or technical contexts to praise clarity and simplicity.
Tips.example: The elegance of her thesis was commended by the professors.

senses.de: The quality of being exceptionally beautiful and simple
senses.ex: The elegance of the sculpture left everyone awestruck.

Tips.title: Art Appreciation
Tips.description: Describes art that is both visually stunning and uncomplicated, provoking thought or emotion.
Tips.example: The elegant lines of the painting captivated the audience.

Tips.title: Emphasizes Form
Tips.description: Highlights the beauty in the structure, shape, or form of the subject.
Tips.example: The sculpture exhibited an innate elegance.

Tips.title: Timeless Appeal
Tips.description: Art with elegance is often considered timeless and universally admired.
Tips.example: The old building has retained its architectural elegance.

senses.de: The attribute of being tastefully designed, decorated, and maintaining an aura of luxury
senses.ex: The hotel is known for its elegance and charm.

Tips.title: Luxurious Connotation
Tips.description: Indicates a high level of quality and comfort, often associated with wealth.
Tips.example: The elegance of the hotel's lobby was truly impressive.

Tips.title: Attention to Detail
Tips.description: Refers to attentiveness to fine details that contribute to an overall luxurious feeling.
Tips.example: The elegance of the table setting did not go unnoticed.

Tips.title: Design Aesthetics
Tips.description: About making spaces or objects both functional and visually pleasing.
Tips.example: Her home's elegant design combined beauty with practicality.

Beauty.wordDefinition:
Beauty refers to something that is pleasing to the senses or the eye, while elegance is more refined and suggests simplicity and sophistication.

Beauty can be found in things that are vibrant and colorful or even in nature such as a flower, while elegance can be found in more subdued forms such as a black dress or a simple piece of jewelry.

Beauty tends to be more subjective and can vary greatly from person to person, while elegance is a more specific quality that suggests a certain level of taste and refinement.

Charm.wordDefinition:
Charm refers to the ability to attract someone through charisma, likability, or a pleasing personality. It's applicable in personal relationships and social situations.

Someone who is charming can make you feel comfortable and happy around them.

Charm is more about personality and social interactions, while elegance is more about appearance and formal situations.

Finesse.wordDefinition:
Elegance refers to the quality of being graceful and stylish in appearance or manner, whereas finesse refers to the skillful and delicate handling of a situation or task.

For example, a person may have elegance in the way they dress and carry themselves, while finesse is required when handling delicate objects or situations, such as performing surgery or resolving a conflict.

Elegance is more related to aesthetics, while finesse is more related to skillful execution.

Polish.wordDefinition:
Polish refers to the level of smoothness and shine on a surface.

Elegance is about a refined and sophisticated quality, while polish refers to a high level of smoothness, shine, and professionalism.

Refinement.wordDefinition:
Elegance refers to the quality of being graceful and stylish, particularly in appearance or behavior. Refinement refers to the quality of being polished or improved, often through careful and deliberate effort.

Refinement is more applicable to the quality of an object or an idea, implying that it has been improved or perfected through careful work or attention to detail.

Sophisticated.wordDefinition:
Sophisticated refers to something being intellectually advanced, complex or worldly. It often relates to knowledge or taste.

For example, a person might be described as sophisticated if they have a deep understanding of art, music or literature.

Elegance is more focused on appearance or style, while sophisticated is more focused on knowledge or taste. Both words can describe people, objects, or ideas, and can be used in a variety of situations.

Style.wordDefinition:
Style refers to the way something is designed or presented, often associated with fashion and personal expression.

Elegance can be applicable in situations such as a fancy dinner party, while style can be applicable in everyday fashion choices.

Taste.wordDefinition:
Taste refers to personal preference or judgement regarding what is aesthetically pleasing or appropriate. It is applicable when describing someone's choices in fashion, art, music, or food, such as having good taste in selecting clothes or having a refined taste in trying different cuisines.

Elegance pertains to the quality or state of something, while taste pertains to personal preference or judgement.

quotes.Text: At least in part, people are attracted to subjects where they can identify at a basic level with the people who do it. The extraordinary aesthetic of the natural world is not obvious to someone who never leaves the inner city. Appreciation of the elegance and power of physical law is an acquired taste.
quotes.Title: American Scientist
quotes.Name: Margaret Geller

quotes.Text: Physical elegance, which is what I am talking about here, comes from the body. This is no superficial matter, but rather the way that man found to honour the way he places his two feet on the ground.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Novelist
quotes.Name: Paulo Coelho

quotes.Text: Not only did she represent inner and outer beauty and elegance, but all the work she did at the end of her life touched so many people. She created this extraordinary legacy.
quotes.Name: Sean Hepburn Ferrer

quotes.Text: There will always be a desire for something new, fresh and innovative, as well as a yearning and respect for timeless elegance and beauty.
quotes.Title: Danish Model
quotes.Name: Helena Christensen

quotes.Text: Don't get me wrong, I admire elegance and have an appreciation of the finer things in life. But to me, beauty lies in simplicity.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Mark Hyman

quotes.Text: True icons are larger than life, unforgettable with an elegance that's mesmerizingly timeless.
quotes.Title: French Businessman
quotes.Name: Francois Nars

quotes.Text: Shoes for men are about elegance or wealth; they are not playing with the inner character.
quotes.Title: French Designer
quotes.Name: Christian Louboutin

quotes.Text: I admire those people who hold on to their elegance in old age but I'd rather have fun.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Heather Graham

quotes.Text: The elegance of a really good screenplay, I admire it. I can't do it.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Janet Fitch

quotes.Text: If you are out to describe the truth, leave elegance to the tailor.
quotes.Title: German Physicist
quotes.Name: Albert Einstein
